column1: 16;"1206224602";"2022-07-19 09:34:37";"2022-07-19 10:29:24";"2";"experiment24";"07:09";"1";"kv";"5 - strongly agree";"2";"4";"2";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"2";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"I think the notation is easy to use but I am not sure if it would be easy to use without the video instructions before. column3: it was easy.

column1: Sometimes I had to close the pop-up windows from the help section to see what my tasks are. It did not really mattered but I noticed it.

I also noticed that it was a little bit hard to scroll to the left if the task had a long text. It jumped to the end of the text (to the right) when I scrolled to the left. ";"experiment25";"6:55";"2";"nl";"2";"4";"2";"3";"4";"2";"3";"5 - strongly agree";"3";"3";"For me

column3: e.g. to
column4: with
column5: which - these are small words that I will forget a lot to add and that is why I think that the notation would be more error prone.

column1: I also noticed that in the instructions there once was the word ""Add"" but I had to use the command ""Set"". So this was a little bit confusing. Fortunately
column2: there were this information pop-up window that are well described
column3: otherwise I would've made the mistake to use the command ""Add"" and get an error.

column1: I would not like to use the notation but I can imagine that people without any knowledge about programming could think the notation is easy to use because they can use ""normal"" or full text to describe the commands.

Additonally it is really important that in the video the speaker tell the user that the module won't need an ID.";"2nd place";"1st place";"see feedbacks before :)";"5 - strongly agree";"5 - strongly agree";"4";"4";"";"No"

column2: as for the interface the help page gets in conflict with the coding window. It would be nice to have the possibility to copy and paste the examples and adapt them to the current needs. It seemed less consistent
column2: I felt that I had to use unnecessary adverbs
column3: it was more spurious and not as easy to remember. If I 'program' a script
column4: a 'real' programming language with a clear structure would feel more natural and easier to learn and remember (without having to constantly refer to the example scripts).";"2nd place";"1st place";"Both key-value notation and natural-language notation are easy enough
column5: but the key-value notation is more consistent and easier to memorize (at least to me). I have limited programming experience
column6: but I do program my lecture slides in Latex
column7: as I find this far more easier than drag-and-drop in PowerPoint.";"4";"4";"4";"5 - strongly agree";"I find video editing (in Linux with KdenLive) quite cumbersome and find it hard to work with the graphical timeline. For me
column8: a programming approach would work much better. Also
column9: I could more easily scroll back to check whether I defined all the timepoints and other things that I wanted to define (it gives me a better overview).

column1: In terms of logic
column2: it struck me as odd that I was allowed to already add material to the video before I defined them. In programming
column3: using or referring to variables before you defined them
column4: is strongly discouraged. I also think that for humans it is more logical to first define/create all items and then integrate them.";"No"

column1: 27;"1082741466";"2022-08-11 12:32:07";"2022-08-11 13:51:13";"2";"experiment57";"07:22";"1";"kv";"5 - strongly agree";"1 - strongly disagree";"5 - strongly agree";"1 - strongly disagree";"5 - strongly agree";"2";"4";"2";"5 - strongly agree";"1 - strongly disagree";"In general
column2: I enjoyed the editing process very much. I think the syntax is very well-thought. However
column3: I have a couple of suggestions:

column1: 1. In ""video""
column2: the URL key is upper-case while all other keys are lower-case
column3: why not just keep the url key lower-case as well? Also
column4: it would be nice for consistency and probably security to enclose the URL value in parentheses in the same way as strings.

column1: 2. In ""question""
column2: the word ""question"" is used both as a classname and as keyword
column3: this might confuse some users. I would suggest changing the key name to ""body"" or something similar. Also
column4: the structure of the answer key where text strings are interchanging with boolean wrong/correct values may lead to confusion and errors
column5: I would suggest using some nested key-value structure there
column9: correct)). (Maybe there is an even better way to do it). While it would make the notation more complicated
column11: which will be beneficial to some users.";"experiment60";"07:40";"2";"nl";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"2";"1 - strongly disagree";"3";"3";"2";"5 - strongly agree";"2";"1 - strongly disagree";"Although my answers may be biased as at this point I am implicitly comparing the ""natural-language"" notation with the key-value notation
column12: in general my experience with the ""natural-language"" one is rather unpleasant. While the usage of ""create"" vs ""set"" commands at least makes sense
column13: the sudden introduction of the ""add"" command is really confusing. Why does one ""add"" timestamps to the video but does not ""add"" answers to question

column1: While this notation is more similar to imperative programming languages
column2: where one actively ""creates"" objects and ""sets"" their properties
column3: the attempt to make it sound more like a natural language with the excessive use of ""with""
column6: etc. makes the script so ridiculous that I would be more happy with something completely ""technical"" like v1.url=""youtube.com/something"" rathet than ""Set URL of v1 to youtube.com/something"".";"2nd place";"1st place";"The key-value notation is a declarative one
column7: and this is no surprise it is more convenient for creating static content like such learning modules
column9: which is also declarative and has been used successfully to structure web pages for the last 3 decades. It just feels natural.

column1: The ""natural-language"" notation looks like an imperative programming language with an excessive amount of prepositions and rather weird word order
column2: which in my opinion takes the worst from both worlds: imperative programming languages and natural languages. First
column3: in contrast to the argument I had for the key-value notation
column4: one would seldom use an imperative programming language to create content manually. It does makes sense to use it for automated content generation
column5: e.g. you have a ready database with video URLs
column6: course titles and texts and you want to automatically generate similar web pages for them
column7: but for a case where every page is to some extent uniquely handcrafted it is just a massive overkill. Second
column8: the attempt to make it sound more like natural language did not work out nicely in my opinion. While I clearly see the purpose behind it
column9: which is to make the language more appealing to non-technical users
column10: the excessive usage of prepositions like ""of""
column12: etc. just makes the text look clumsy. On top of that
column13: the word order required to make it sound more natural
column14: i.e. set attribute of id to value
column15: just hurts a programmer's eye a bit.";"4";"5 - strongly agree";"5 - strongly agree";"5 - strongly agree";"The comparison of the two notations is yet another instance of the somewhat classical declarative vs imperative debate. Are there no existing studies on which one fits better for the purpose? ";"Yes"

column1: 28;"151743211";"2022-08-16 14:31:29";"2022-08-16 15:56:09";"2";"experiment68";"11:45";"1";"kv";"3";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"2";"2";"1 - strongly disagree";"The information windows that pops when clicking the buttons (e.g. ""Video""
column2: ""Question"") covers a part of the code and the window isn't moveable. It would be nice to be able to drag the window.

column1: It would also be nice if the identifiers (e.g. ""URL""
column2: ""title"") were colored
column3: just to give the user a confirmation.

column1: Other than that
column2: it was really easy to navigate the tool and everything was clear. I finished successfully and I didn't find it difficult. My first general impression however is that it might be nice to have some interactive elements
column3: for example: drag a box titled ""video"" into the storyboard editing field (bottom left box) which will automatically insert the code. It will then prompt you to insert a title
column4: if you want timestamps
column5: etc. This might be more intuitive and faster than writing code.

column1: ;experiment71";"22:15";"2";"nl";"3";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"2";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"3";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"This natural language notation was more intuitive to use and therefore is faster. I finished ""successfully"" within 22 minutes
column2: because I was stuck on an error for 15 minutes. The error feedback (""extra characters after close-quote"") wasn't helpful
column3: as it didn't tell me what line this was on and actually mislead me to looking for the error in the wrong places.

column1: The actual mistake I made was I used the wrong syntax for the answers of the question. I used a notation similar to that of the first experiment: ""Set answer of q1 to (""Answer 1""
column2: correct ""Answer 2""
column3: wrong) instead of: ""Set answer of q1 to ""Answer 1"" which is correct
column4: Set answer of q1 to ""Answer 2"" which is false"". This was simply a mistake on my part and not due to a flaw of the natural language notation. I believe that now I would be more confident and also faster using this notation over the previous one!";"1st place";"2nd place";"As stated previously
column5: i find the natural-language notation to be more intuitive and therefore faster to use.";"5 - strongly agree";"3";"2";"5 - strongly agree";"I feel like the combination of a GUI and textual notation is the best. The GUI would be good for creating the main structure of the module (what goes where
column6: how big should the textfield or embedded video be
column7: etc). And the textual notation would be good for further refinements (e.g. creating the question/answer form
column9: etc). You should be able to switch between GUI and textual notation in my opinion!";"Yes"

column2: as I used them as a template for each command and also used them to check when I got an error message in the preview. However

set/add was very confusing in the natural language and didn't add any additional value as far as I could tell. Typing out a long instruction seemed unnecessary after the key value task";"3";"3";"2";"4";"I liked being able to see the ""plan"" in the textual notation. I would not use it as the starting point for a GUI environment - it would be either/or (or ""play""/check it in the GUI and come back to make changes in the text).

I think it depends very much on the usability/user-friendliness of the GUI. This would definitely be better than Learn on its own because you can integrate questions and breaks into the video. However
column2: I have also used Planet eStream's editing and quiz function and I would say it's 50/50: writing questions directly into a box is still simpler than writing out text-based commands BUT getting started did seem to be easier and ""cleaner"" than it was with Planet eStream (although maybe that's because the experiment was set up so clearly). Once I got used to the system of the key value notation it seemed very straightforward.

column1: One minor point: YouTube videos are typically measured in minutes:seconds
column2: so converting a time to seconds for the key value is a bit of a pain (and less efficient)
column3: in contrast to clicking on the time bar. If I could enter the time as minutes:seconds I would probably like that better than faffing around with scrolling to the correct point in a GUI.";"Yes"

column1: 37;"1832679888";"2022-08-23 14:33:09";"2022-08-23 15:49:39";"2";"experiment106";"12:35";"1";"kv";"3";"3";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"2";"3";"4";"5 - strongly agree";"3";"I missed some sort of code-completion or keyword suggestion features like in many programming EDIs.";"experiment107";"12:38";"2";"nl";"2";"3";"2";"3";"2";"3";"4";"4";"5 - strongly agree";"3";"It was ok. Due to the natural language constructs it was a little bit more difficult to remember how to write the statement. E.g. the ""wich is"" part of Questions.
I dont know the other commands available in this notation
column2: but i would suggest to create a language with only few but consistent keywords (e.g. ""which is"" is also used in an ""if"" statement).

column1: It was also more cumbersome
column2: since i had to write more words.";"2nd place";"1st place";"For me as a person with experience in C++ Programming
column3: the simpler notation gets a higher rank. For me it is easier to use and to read. But thats due to my experience with programming languages.

column1: However
column2: i think the natural language version
column3: like a higher programming language
column4: could be more effective
column5: when it comes to more complex and more modularized Systems. That is
column6: if more keywords are added to the language
column7: then you have standardized keywords like ""create""
column8: you allready know and do not need to learn the syntax. In addition
column9: when the system allows to add libraries or modules to integrate new functionality
column10: then a collection of standardized keywords is necessary. Otherwise a library is always introducing new commands

However some commands could be grouped together to avoid possible errors with wrong IDs (e.g. title + body).";"ID: experiment122";"07:40";"2";"nl";"3";"2";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"4";"2";"3";"3";"4";"1 - strongly disagree";"This notation is focused on actions instead of elements. column2: but not as easy as the first one.";"1st place";"1st place";"Both notations are easy to use
column3: however I think that programming experiece is more important for the key-value notation. Therefore
